question: A stack follows the Last In, First Out (LIFO) principle.
In a stack, elements are removed using the push operation.
Stacks are commonly used in recursion to store function calls.
Postfix notation requires parentheses to determine operator precedence.
Stacks can be used to evaluate expressions in postfix notation.
In infix notation, the operator appears before the operands.
Postfix notation is also known as Reverse Polish Notation (RPN).
Postfix notation eliminates the need for parentheses in expressions.
In postfix notation, the expression (A + B) * C is written as A B + C *.
In postfix evaluation, operators are pushed onto the stack before operands.
The precedence of the multiplication (*) operator is lower than that of the addition (+) operator.
The pop operation removes an element from the bottom of the stack.
A stack can be implemented using an array or a linked list.
A stack overflow occurs when an attempt is made to push an element onto a full stack.
Stacks are used in function call management in programming languages.
In postfix notation, the expression A B C + * means (A * (B + C)).
Stacks can be used to check balanced parentheses in an expression.
The push operation removes an element from the stack.
Postfix expressions can be evaluated using a single scan of the expression.
In a stack, the top element is always the most recently added element.
